III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Youth nutrition
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff did not provide Youth A with breakfast on 9/27/24.
Investigation On 9/27/24 Complainant reported that Youth A ran from
placement to MDHHS and stated he was not given breakfast, and
that staff were not nice to him. Complainant was contacted on
9/27/24 and reported that Youth A was not upset or in distress
when they spoke with him. Youth A reported to Complainant that
he felt safe and was not fearful to return to the facility.
Interviews:
Foster Care Worker was contacted by email on 10/1/24. Foster
Care Worker reported that Youth A continued to reside at the
facility, but he was feeling ill. Foster Care Worker did not have any
concerns about the placement. Follow-up occurred with Foster
Care Worker on 10/8/24. Foster Care Worker visited with Youth A
on 9/27/24 and he appeared not to be upset. Youth A had
attempted to skip school on a few occasions, due to feeling
overwhelmed at school. However, the agency was working hard to
advocate for him and help him use coping skills. The facility also
implemented a safety plan for Youth A to use coping skills when
he is upset. It was identified that one of Youth A’s triggers is being
told “no”. Youth A agreed not to run when upset. Youth A will take
time alone, listen to music, or go outside to play basketball or
swing. Foster Care Worker noted a discussion with Youth A about
the importance of being truthful and not exaggerating or adjusting
“stories”.
Administrator was contacted by email on 10/2/24 and reported
that Youth A had refused to attend school all week, stating that he
was sick. Administrator provided copies of incident reports to
DCWL.
Youth A was interviewed on-site at the facility on 10/4/24. Youth
A reported he did not get breakfast on 9/27/24. Youth A clarified
that he was offered applesauce and juice, when everyone else
2

had a sausage English muffin. Youth A stated that he did not have
a problem with eating applesauce, but he wanted sausage that
morning. Youth A stated that staff did not want him to eat the
sausage, as he had been complaining of having an upset
stomach. Youth A was upset with staff and ran from the facility.
Youth A stated he never missed a meal prior to this. Youth A
returned to the facility later that day and had lunch and dinner.
Youth A identified Staff 1 and Staff 2 as the staff he spoke with
about breakfast.
Staff 1 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 1 reported
that on 9/27/24 Youth A reported he had a stomachache and
wanted to miss school. Staff 1 told Youth A that he probably
should not have greasy breakfast sausage if he had an upset
stomach. Staff 1 asked Staff 2 if they could make some soup or
applesauce for Youth A, as it would be easier on his stomach.
Youth A became upset and stormed out. Staff 1 stated that he
was just trying to help Youth A avoid anything that may make him
feel worse. Staff 1 felt that applesauce would not be too heavy.
Staff 1 stated Youth A was not denied breakfast.
Staff 2 was interviewed by phone on 10/28/24. Staff 2 reported
that she was the cook at the facility on 9/27/24. Staff 2 observed
Youth A to say that he had a stomachache and did not feel able to
go to school. Staff 2 recalled that Staff 1 suggested a light
breakfast for Youth A, to avoid further upsetting his stomach. Staff
1 suggested some soup. Youth A became upset and ran out of the
facility. Staff 2 stated that breakfast that morning was sausage
and muffins, which may have been too greasy for an upset
stomach. Staff 2 did not feel anyone was trying to keep Youth A
from eating. Rather staff were trying to provide an alternative, so
he would not feel worse.
Residential Director emailed DCWL on 10/29/24. Residential
Director stated that the facility does not have policy regarding
meals for sick youth. However, they follow pediatric
recommendations for the BRAT diet.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident report dated 9/27/24 written by Residential
Director. The report stated that the agency was contacted
by the local MDHHS office as Youth A went there and told
staff he was “not getting fed”. The day prior, Youth A came
home from school stating he had a stomachache and threw
up. On the morning of 9/27/24 Youth A reported he was still
feeling unwell. Staff tried to offer Youth A items that would
3

not further upset his stomach. Youth A did not like what
was offered and went AWOL next door to the MDHHS
office. Residential Director went to the MDHHS office and
spoke with a supervisor, then returned Youth A to the
facility.
• Incident report dated 9/27/24 written by Staff 1 was
consistent with the interview completed on 10/28/24.
• Incident report dated 9/27/24 written by Staff 2 was
consistent with the interview completed on 10/28/24.
Analysis Based on an interview with Youth A, he was not denied breakfast.
Per the youth, Staff 1 and Staff 2 an alternative breakfast was
offered as the youth was feeling unwell.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff are not nice to Youth A.
Investigation During an interview with DCWL on 10/4/24, Youth A clarified that
when he stated staff are “not nice” he meant that he was upset
with them for not allowing him to have what he wanted for
breakfast. Youth A also stated he was upset that staff wanted him
to go to school that day. Youth A denied any other occurrences of
staff being “not nice”.
Analysis An interview with Youth A determined that he was upset when he
made the allegation and there was no indication staff did anything
inappropriate.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
